programme.title: SportsCenter
programme.desc: The latest news, highlights and inside information from every corner of the sports world is presented each day on "SportsCenter," ESPN's first-ever program when the network debuted in September of 1979. The flagship series airs an evening edition and a brand new late-night show each weekday before the stage is cleared for a live "SportsCenter" morning block that emphasizes fast-paced, highlights-driven reports and what's new on social media platforms.

programme.title: Get Up
programme.desc: ESPN's morning show features host Mike Greenberg with a rotating and diverse group of analysts opining about and analyzing the latest news from the world of sports. The two-hour, personality-driven show originates from Manhattan's South Street Seaport, a locale that attracts high-profile guests. Greenberg, aka "Greeny," is formerly one-half of ESPN Radio's longtime "Mike & Mike" morning show.

programme.title: First Take
programme.desc: Stephen A. Smith joins host Molly Qerim on this weekday morning sports debate show. Smith provides his expert takes on the day's trending sports topics and under-the-radar news. They're regularly joined by veteran analysts and the top guests in sports and entertainment.

programme.title: The Pat McAfee Show
programme.desc: Former NFL punter Pat McAfee brings his humor and candor to the microphone to highlight the day's top stories.

programme.title: SportsCenter
programme.desc: The latest news, highlights and inside information from every corner of the sports world is presented each day on "SportsCenter," ESPN's first-ever program when the network debuted in September of 1979. The flagship series airs an evening edition and a brand new late-night show each weekday before the stage is cleared for a live "SportsCenter" morning block that emphasizes fast-paced, highlights-driven reports and what's new on social media platforms.

programme.title: NBA Today
programme.desc: In-depth, comprehensive daily coverage of all aspects of the NBA from expert analysts.

programme.title: NFL Live
programme.desc: Host Laura Rutledge takes the helm of this weekday show featuring the likes of Marcus Spears, Dan Orlovsky, Mina Kimes, and Adam Schefter. The "NFL Live" crew entertains fans while offering all the latest news and analysis from across the NFL.

programme.title: Around the Horn
programme.desc: Hosted by Tony Reali in the ESPN studio and joined via satellite by four panelists from across the country, the team debates popular sports stories. Reali acts as moderator, giving points for well-made arguments and deducting points for those who inspire him to hit the "mute" button. At the end of the show, whomever Reali deems the winner has 30 seconds without interruption to voice their final opinions on any topic they want.

programme.title: Pardon the Interruption
programme.desc: The debate is the story in this fast-paced, half-hour series hosted by former Washington Post sportswriters Tony Kornheiser and Michael Wilbon. The pair engage in high-energy discussions, conduct interviews and often argue over topics not even related to sports. Other sports reporters appear as guests and offer opinions on the top stories of the day.

programme.desc: The latest news, highlights and inside information from every corner of the sports world is presented each day on "SportsCenter," ESPN's first-ever program when the network debuted in September of 1979. The flagship series airs an evening edition and a brand new late-night show each weekday before the stage is cleared for a live "SportsCenter" morning block that emphasizes fast-paced, highlights-driven reports and what's new on social media platforms.

programme.title: Get Up
programme.desc: ESPN's morning show features host Mike Greenberg with a rotating and diverse group of analysts opining about and analyzing the latest news from the world of sports. The two-hour, personality-driven show originates from Manhattan's South Street Seaport, a locale that attracts high-profile guests. Greenberg, aka "Greeny," is formerly one-half of ESPN Radio's longtime "Mike & Mike" morning show.

programme.title: College Basketball
programme.desc: The No. 4 Blue Devils (12-2, 4-0) host the Panthers (12-2, 3-0) for an ACC contest. Last season, Pittsburgh scored just its third win in 14 tries against Duke since joining the ACC. Duke has won eight in a row, while Pitt has claimed five straight.

programme.title: College Basketball
programme.desc: The No. 4 Blue Devils (13-2, 5-0 ACC) host the Fighting Irish (7-8, 1-3). Duke has won nine in a row overall, and is 11-1 versus Notre Dame since 2016-17 after winning a pair last season by a combined 26 points. The Irish have dropped three straight.

programme.title: College Basketball
programme.desc: Men's college basketball action.

programme.title: College Basketball
programme.desc: Freshman sensation Cooper Flagg and the No. 2 Blue Devils (16-2, 8-0 ACC) visit the Demon Deacons (15-4, 7-1). Duke has won 12 straight games. Flagg, a 6-foot-9 guard, averages team highs of 19.2 points, 8.1 rebounds and 4.1 assists per outing.

programme.title: College Basketball
programme.desc: The No. 2 Blue Devils entertain the Wolfpack in ACC play. Duke is 11-0 at home this season, with freshman sensation Cooper Flagg averaging 18 points per game. NC State has won its last two contests against Duke, in the 2024 ACC and NCAA Tournaments.

programme.title: College Basketball
programme.desc: Cooper Flagg gets his first taste of the Duke-North Carolina rivalry as his No. 2 Blue Devils host. Flagg has been the driving force behind Duke's 14-game win streak. The freshman leads the Blue Devils in points, rebounds, assists, and blocks.

programme.title: Southern Hoops: A History of SEC Basketball
programme.desc: Adolph Rupp comes to the University of Kentucky in 1930, two years before the SEC is formed, and his Wildcats go on to dominate play in the conference for decades. Meanwhile, a future coaching legend later known as Pat Summitt is born in Tennessee.

programme.title: Southern Hoops: A History of SEC Basketball
programme.desc: Texas Western's historic win over Adolph Rupp's Kentucky team in the 1966 NCAA final marks a turning point in the SEC. Vanderbilt's Perry Wallace becomes the conference's first Black player, while at LSU, Pete Maravich rewrites the record books.

programme.title: Southern Hoops: A History of SEC Basketball
programme.desc: Dale Brown brings an infectious personality to LSU while Pat Summitt begins her legendary coaching career at Tennessee. And the year after Adolph Rupp's death in 1977, his successor Joe B. Hall leads Kentucky to its first NCAA title in 20 years.

programme.title: Southern Hoops: A History of SEC Basketball
programme.desc: Georgia's Dominique Wilkins and Auburn's Charles Barkley headline the SEC's successes in the early 1980s, while LSU's Dale Brown takes two teams to the Final Four. Pat Summitt wins her first two national titles at Tennessee.

programme.title: Southern Hoops: A History of SEC Basketball
programme.desc: Arkansas joins the SEC and becomes one of the conference's top teams, led by fiery coach Nolan Richardson and his "40 Minutes of Hell" attack. Kentucky returns to prominence, and at Tennessee, Pat Summitt wins three straight NCAA titles.

programme.title: Southern Hoops: A History of SEC Basketball
programme.desc: In his first year at Kentucky, Tubby Smith becomes the third Black coach ever to win a national title. Florida's back-to-back NCAA crowns mark the rise of a new power. The Lady Vols win 2 straight NCAA titles as LSU reaches 5 straight Final Fours.

programme.title: Southern Hoops: A History of SEC Basketball
programme.desc: John Calipari continues the winning tradition at Kentucky with a national championship in 2012. Four years later, Pat Summitt passes away after battling early-onset Alzheimer's disease. Dawn Staley leads South Carolina to a pair of NCAA titles.

programme.title: TrueSouth
programme.desc: Sands, the soul food café, cooks oxtails and cabbage and ropy okra; Arnold's Country Kitchen, Kahlil Arnold dishes created corn, hashed turnip greens, and fried green tomatoes; the differences between black and white cooking come into focus.

programme.title: TrueSouth
programme.desc: Herby K's is a 1936 vintage beer garden and fry house. Lucky Palace serves wol-fried-t-bones and pork egg foo young. Both of these restaurants are survivors, like Shreveport itself.
